newsitem.title: UK: North Sea mixed as Brent corrects, grades hold firm.
newsitem.headline: North Sea mixed as Brent corrects, grades hold firm.

text.p: North Sea crudes were mixed on Thursday as benchmark Dated Brent fell sharply and other grades held up amid sustained demand for second half June barrels, traders said.
Dated Brent traded early at July Brent -24 cents, a fall of nearly 30 cents on the last reported deal as the aggressive buyer of recent days turned seller.
Traders said Brent was due for a fall and Brent CFDs barely flinched. Next week's June 2-6 dates eased just a couple of cents to talk at July Brent -32/-29 cents.
July Brent gained 36 cents to $19.60 a barrel by 1730 GMT.
Dealers said Brent's outright gains came as early losses prompted by mildly bearish builds in U.S. crude and gasoline stocks petered out and reversed on technical strength.
Intermonth Brent cash spreads were little changed, June/July trading between -20 and -16 cents and July/August at -13 and -12 cents.
Two Brents turning wet on Thursday were clocked to BP and Morgan Stanley. A third was kept by Phibro, traders said.
Other spot North Sea grades held their differentials despite Brent's sharp slide, Ekofisk, Forties and Flotta all trading at broadly unchanged levels.
Three third decade June cargoes of Forties traded at around Dated Brent +32/+33 cents while two Ekofisks due to load around June 16-18 fetched July Brent +18 and +20 cents.
But while cheaper Brent was helping refinery margins and encouraging a few buyers back into the market, it was prompting some to hold back in anticipation of softer differentials.
"We've seen some interest but since the lower Brent deal a few people have been holding back," said a North Sea producer.
The Mediterranean market was quiet with traders watching the impact of delays at the Russian Black Sea port of Novorossiisk after an oil spill earlier this week.
The port was operating with only two berths early on Thursday but a third, berth number six, was due to reopen at about 1800 local time.
West African markets were also thin with most June fob avails placed and traders waiting for the release of July loading programmes for Nigerian export streams.
The Indian Oil Corp (IOC) awarded two VLCCs of Nigerian crude in its July purchase tender, one of Escravos to Chevron and one of Qua Iboe to Mobil, traders said.
